repnme.cdata!:
Guyana - Financial Sector and Business
            Environment Credit, Private Sector Development Adjustment
            Credit, and,  Financial and Private Sector Institutional
            Development Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit gives mixed results in rating
            the three operations, concurring, or not with the
            Implementation Completion (ICR) reports' ratings, as
            follows. It downgrades the Financial Sector and Business
            Environment (FSBEP) Project outcome to unsatisfactory, its
            sustainability to unlikely, institutional development
            impacts to negligible, including both Bank and Borrower
            performances to unsatisfactory; similarly, the Private
            Sector Development Adjustment Credit (PSDAC) is downgraded
            to moderately satisfactory outcomes, unlikely
            sustainability, modest institutional development impacts,
            satisfactory Bank performance, although concurs with a
            satisfactory Borrower performance; and, ratings on the
            Financial and Private Sector Institutional Development
            (FPSIDP) are also downgraded to unsatisfactory project
            outcomes, unlikely sustainability, and negligible
            institutional development impacts, yet, concurs with
            satisfactory performances by the Bank and Borrower. Some of
            the main lessons from these projects suggest that: The
            ethnic divide, distrust, and governance problems, are the
            key constraints to improving the environment for private
            sector development (PSD), and fostering sustainable growth
            in Guyana. At the project level, all future Bank operations,
            including their components and processes (e.g. consultations
            on project design, hiring of consultants, procurement,
            selection of trainees, choice of regulatory options, etc.),
            should address the way to at least, avoid deepening
            distrust, and if possible, serve to build trust across the
            racial divide. Transparency should be the key watchword for
            both the Government, and donors. In addition, more
            diagnostic work on incentives, institutions, and social
            capital is needed, with a view to identifying strategies,
            and tactics for rationalizing incentives, building
            sustainable institutions, and fostering social capital.
            Understanding the political economy is essential to project
            choice, and design.

repnme.cdata!:
Guyana - Financial Sector and Business
            Environment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall project outcome was
            satisfactory: the goals of reducing the state s role in the
            economy, improving the solvency and efficiency of financial
            intermediation, and strengthening banking supervision were
            satisfactorily met. On the other hand, the restructuring of
            the new Guyana National Cooperative Bank was unsatisfactory;
            and the goal of enhancing the business environment was
            adjudged marginally unsatisfactory. Both World Bank and
            Borrower performances were satisfactory overall. The
            following are the main lessons learned: Inter-agency
            arrangements both financial and institutional and, in
            particular, the absence of documentation delayed the
            privatization process. Wide disparity in the value of the
            same asset base made it difficult for the Privatization Unit
            to arrive at the true value of enterprise assets. Although
            worker participation was a key objective, the financial
            status of many workers and the large asset base of most
            enterprises made this difficult. The investment agency
            (GO-INVEST) has not been as effective as expected due to
            several changes in the leadership, thereby delaying capacity
            building. When the financial situation of the newly merged
            Guyana National Cooperative Bank (GNCB) deteriorated, the
            government decided to contract a new management team, which
            has been able to stem further losses of the bank's portfolio.

18152589.theme: Other financial and private sector development,State-owned enterprise restructuring and privatization,Regulation and competition policy,Macroeconomic management
18152589.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Economic management

repnme.cdata!:
Guyana - Financial Sector and Business
            Environment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Financial Sector
            and Business Environment Project are to implement
            sustainable institution building mechanisms supporting the
            financial and private sector, and to facilitate the
            effective implementation of policy measures supported by the
            private sector development adjustment credit. The project
            will achieve these objectives through the following
            components. The first component will seek to strengthen
            financial sector operation and regulation through: a)
            support to the Central Bank in banking supervision through
            regulatory advice, training and equipment; b) support the
            Central Bank in improving monetary management through
            assistance in developing procedures and related staff
            training; and c) support in restructuring of state-owned
            financial institutions. The second component seeks, through
            privatization, to transfer public ownership of a majority of
            public enterprises to private hands and in this manner, to
            also stimulate investment. The third component aims to
            strengthen the business environment through support to the
            Office of GO-INVEST (the Guyana Office Investment) with
            training of staff to help simplify procedures for foreign
            investors, and b) consultant support in the development of
            regulations under the Companies Act and training of staff of
            the Registry of Companies to strengthen its capacity to
            implement this Act.

Guyana - Financial Sector and Business
            Environment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Financial Sector
            and Business Environment Project are to implement
            sustainable institution building mechanisms supporting the
            financial and private sector, and to facilitate the
            effective implementation of policy measures supported by the
            private sector development adjustment credit. The project
            will achieve these objectives through the following
            components. The first component will seek to strengthen
            financial sector operation and regulation through: a)
            support to the Central Bank in banking supervision through
            regulatory advice, training and equipment; b) support the
            Central Bank in improving monetary management through

            training; and c) support in restructuring of state-owned
            financial institutions. The second component seeks, through
            privatization, to transfer public ownership of a majority of
            public enterprises to private hands and in this manner, to
